title: Prefigurative Community Building (Part 37): Street Medics and Crisis Response Collectives - A Power With Model of Care and Safety
summary: A guide to building community-led street medic and crisis response teams that distribute knowledge, share responsibility, and coordinate through care rather than hierarchy.

Community.summary: Build networks of community-controlled emergency response and care that challenge state monopolies on safety.

level0: Form a care circle with shared values around community care and consent
Get basic first aid and trauma-informed care training
Practice de-escalation and witnessing techniques in low-risk situations
level1: Identify local emergency response gaps and community safety needs
Build mobile first-aid kits and establish communication protocols
Train your team in scenario-based emergency response drills
level2: Provide street medic support at protests and community events
Embed with community networks and build relationships with other safety groups
Offer first aid trainings and safety workshops to broader community
level3: Support formation of additional autonomous street medic collectives
Build lasting infrastructure for community-controlled emergency response
Advocate for policies that reduce reliance on police-based emergency response

Knowledge.summary: Share medical and safety knowledge horizontally while building community capacity for emergency response.

level0: Learn basic street medic skills like wound care, heat exhaustion, and psychological first aid
Study successful street medic collectives and community response projects
level1: Practice trauma-informed and consent-based medical care approaches
Document your collective's protocols and safety practices
Learn about legal rights and responsibilities for street medic work
level2: Host workshops on street medic skills and community emergency response
Create accessible resources about building crisis response collectives
Share knowledge with other medic collectives and safety organizers
level3: Develop comprehensive street medic organizing toolkits
Research and document impacts of community vs institutional emergency response
Train facilitators and organizers in other communities

Power.summary: Challenge state monopolies on emergency response while building community power through collective care.

level0: Practice community accountability and mutual aid principles in emergency response
Challenge reliance on police and carceral systems for community safety
Build analysis of how community care relates to broader liberation struggles
level1: Organize community members to collectively respond to crises and emergencies
Practice nonviolent intervention and de-escalation in conflict situations
Build collective capacity to protect and care for vulnerable community members
level2: Coordinate street medic activities with other social justice organizing
Challenge systems that criminalize community care and mutual aid
Build political power through grassroots safety and care organizing
level3: Contribute to broader movements for community-controlled safety and care
Advocate for policies that support community emergency response systems
Build lasting infrastructure for community self-determination and collective care
